awd_titl_txt: Exploring Careers and Learning Informally to Prepare for STEM Employment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by designing, implementing, and testing an afterschool internship program that will engage older youth in work-based learning experiences in in STEM fields.  The new model program will link the resources and learning approaches of the Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment (GLOBE) program to career academies where youth from populations underrepresented in STEM fields will gain direct experiences in data collection and analysis through student-led investigations in the geosciences and environmental studies. Two key outcomes of this project will be: (a) Development of a replicable model of an afterschool STEM internship program for informal STEM learning environments and schools across the nation, and (b) Development of a set of measurement tools and approaches that can assess and promote understanding regarding how youth think and feel about science and their possible future roles in science careers.  Participating youth will master scientific practices and become immersed in science culture through opportunities to develop research projects, interact with scientists, and collaborate with fellow student-researchers. In the process, they will develop collaboration and communication skills, and gain an increased sense of identity and agency in science fields.  They will also learn new strategies to attain their career goals. 

In developing and testing the new model of an afterschool program focusing on STEM careers, the project will draw on both existing and emerging knowledge from three areas of inquiry: informal STEM learning, youth development, and work-based learning. The project will bring together theory related to work-based learning and apprenticeship to knowledge about informal STEM learning and youth development, addressing the needs of older youth as they transition to adulthood. The program will also explore the use of measurement tools that address workforce-related student learning goals in addition to social-emotional learning and STEM learning goals, adapting existing tools and developing new tools as needed.  The result will be a replicable model for an afterschool, career-focused internship that facilitates STEM learning and identity, employing youth development principles, such as experiential learning, peer collaboration, adult mentoring, and meaningful contributions to the world beyond school.  The project will use a mixed-methods approach to investigate four research questions:  (1) What aspects of the program are most important for promoting the development of scientific practices, socio-emotional learning, and career skills? (2) How can afterschool informal science learning be designed to address the perceptions and needs of diverse groups, especially those from populations underrepresented in STEM? (3) How do youth make gains in developing facility with STEM practices, key social-emotional outcomes needed in work and civic life, and career development knowledge?  And (4) How do we accurately measure development of scientific practices, socio-emotional learning and career skills?  The project will develop pretest and posttest self-report measures to gauge program influence on social-emotional outcomes and career-related outcomes, and performance-based assessments and rubrics will be used to assess culminating science projects.  Other factors contributing to the success of the new model will be examined through analysis of coach instructional logs, surveys, and questions, as well as participant observations, interviews, and focus groups. Project participants will be youth of ages 14-18 recruited from ten inner-city schools having large populations of students from groups underrepresented in STEM fields.  Participants will meet in teams of approximately 14 interns for a total of 2.5 hours per week for 32 weeks.  Each team will also meet an additional 4-6 times for weekend or overnight outings associated with their study sites.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: EARTH TEAM A CALIFORNIA NONPROFIT PUBLIC BENEFIT CORP

por.por_cntn:
The ECLIPSE program provided an insight on how socio-emotional learning opportunities are helpful in promoting the development of STEM practices and career skills. Consistent with resilience theory, three program features emerged. The skill of Earth Team staff who led the program implementation is a distinctive and instrumental aspect of this project; coaches were knowledgeable, personable, and compassionate. They established caring relationships early in the year and built trust with the youth in the context of safe spaces for positive social interactions. Second, they established high expectations for participation and performance.  Third, students were engaged in meaningful activity and were compensated for their time, signaling that their work was valued and taken seriously.  

The participants in the afterschool informal science learning program were from groups historically underrepresented in STEM, ages 14-17, from low-income families living in urban settings. Many shared interest in environmental justice and wanted to make a difference in their communities and in the world.  They carried out and disseminated original community-based environmental science research projects. They grew their interest in STEM and their awareness of STEM careers, and developed proficiency in a variety of important workplace skills that would be essential for a STEM career.

The project was structured around three core components: STEM Practice, Career Development, and Socio-Emotional Learning. The arrows in our logic model represent the flow of results from the youth’s  engagement with these components.  

The results showed the foundational strength of the social emotional dimension and depict how the youth experience positive trusting relationships, a direct outgrowth of the social and emotional programming. With a strong foundation defined by trust, openness, piqued interest, and high expectations for performance, the youth were primed to participate in STEM practices and activities that support college and career readiness, leading to competence, confidence, STEM identify, and career self-efficacy. 

The follwoing design elements contributed to the positive outcomes:

1. Group size and work-session duration.

Size and duration were two related design features that affected participation and engagement. Team size ranged from 8 to a full team of 14 youth. In contrast to a classroom where there are dozens of students, ECLIPSE coaches were able provided individualized attention at each session. Moreover, the weekly team meetings were two hours long, and weekend meetings four to six hours long.  A small, close-knit group that was together a full school year and that met for extended intimate weekly meetings meant team members had the opportunity to really listen, learn from one another, and build trusting relationships. 

2. Youth interest in environmental science and in social and economic issues.

The coaches were skilled in recognizing when youth were interested in certain topics. They encouraged the youth to follow their interests whether they pertained to research projects, STEM careers, college majors, or other things. Providing interesting, novel, and fun experiences in the localized context of their own communitires worked well as a strategy to invite participation of youth from populations that have historically been excluded from STEM fields.

3. Distributed leadership and peer-to-peer mentoring.

Rich mentoring relationships helped in creating teaching and learning opportunities in which the youth demonstrated leadership, communication, and problem-solving skills. Youth reported that these were areas of growth for them.

4. Immersive experiences and GLOBE research projects.

Hands-on field activities and the doing of authentic science through GLOBE protocols, were fun and motivating. The youth stated that the team meetings were engaging in part because the programming was interactive and immersive in outdoor places. The GLOBE research projects that the youth planned and carried out in their local outdoor environments were an integral feature of the program design and contributed to the development of science practices and competence. 

5. Authentic interactions with active STEM professionals.

The STEM professionals shared perspectives about their academic journeys or how they started in STEM were valuable because they offered unique insights that augmented what the coaches could offer. They shed light on the STEM professional world, raised awareness of multiple career options, and served as role models, inspiring the youth to pursue their goals. 

Measuring social emotional learning, workplace readiness, and proficiency in STEM practices requires multiple approaches and triangulation of data points and measures. The project employed mixed methods: Youth pre-post and real-time self-reports, coach reports of the youth, participant observations, focus groups, and a culminating performance task. Accuracy in measurement was achieved several ways. First, measures were pilot tested with cohorts of youth in focus groups and incremental changes to the instruments were made to meet project needs. Second, repeated measures were used each year. Third, interpretations were “member checked” with the youth and the coaches. Fourth, an authentic performance-based measure was used to assess STEM practice. Finally, data were collected from multiple perspectives which created opportunities to associate different measures and assess the proximity of the data coming from different sources.


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Manuel L Alonso
